Dear Harding:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Linda Tansil, Area Manager, at 734-775-8293.
Sincerely,
Douglas W Turrill, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207 Staff responsibilities
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be
Description directly responsible for all of the following activities:
1

(a) Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care.
Social service workers shall work directly with the children,
their families, and other relevant individuals and be primarily
responsible for the development, implementation, and review
of service plans for the children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegations (1) Services not provided for foster child and bio-mother.
(2) Visits to home not documented, quality visits not
documented.
Investigation Allegation 1
The Chief Administrator was interviewed via video on March
31, 2023.The Chief Administrator reported that an internal
investigation had been conducted by the agency regarding the
allegation described above. The Chief Administrator
acknowledged that services for the biological mother of Foster
Child A were lacking. The Chief Administrator stated, “You won’t
see any collateral referral contacts for services” for the Bio-
Mother. The Chief Administrator reported that drug screens for the
Bio-Mother were occurring but not entered into the social work
contacts. The Chief Administrator reported that the Bio-mother
was not engaged in substance abuse services and the agency did
not follow up with service referrals for the Bio-Mother when she
tested positive for drugs.
The Chief Administrator reported Foster Child A was not engaged
in services such as a trauma assessment and counseling. The
Chief Administrator reported that a Trauma Screening conducted
by the agency on January 5, 2023, for Foster Child A resulted in a
score of eight. The Chief Administrator reported that at that time
Foster Child A should have been referred for counseling however
this was delayed until March 13, 2023. The Chief Administrator
reported that this delay should not have occurred.
The agency Deputy Director was interviewed via video on
May 9, 2023. The Deputy Director reported that the agency foster
care worker did not address a positive drug screen for the Bio-
mother when this occurred on November 8, 2022. The Deputy
Director reported that when the Bio-Mother tested positive for
fentanyl she should have been referred for substance abuse
services and this did not occur. The Deputy Director reported that
the case file did not contain any collateral contacts indicating that
the Bio-Mother was referred for services. The Deputy Director
2

reported that there is one follow up contact with Catholic Human
Services on January 18, 2023, the agency where the Bio-Mother
was seeing a counselor, however there was no other follow up
contacts since that date. The Deputy Director also reported that
the Bio-Mother did have a psychological evaluation however
follow up services are not documented.
The Deputy Director reported that she conducted a trauma
screening for Foster Child A on March 28, 2023, and subsequently
she was referred for a trauma assessment with the Child Trauma
Assessment Center in Kalamazoo, Michigan. The Deputy Director
reported that there was a delay in the agency conducting a trauma
screening and referral for a trauma assessment.
The Deputy Director reported that the agency foster care worker
on the case no longer works for the agency.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
Forensic Fluids Laboratories: Fourteen drug screen reports for
the Bio-Mother were reviewed. The reports are from April 13,
2022, to December 28, 2022. A drug screen report dated
November 8, 2022, indicates a positive for fentanyl.
Psychological Evaluation: An evaluation dated May 24, 2022,
for the Bio-Mother indicates poly substance dependence/abuse
and post-traumatic stress disorder.
Holy Cross Services Parent Agency Treatment Plans: PATP”s
dated September 29, 2022 and January 3, 2023 were reviewed.
The PATP dated September 29, 2022, indicates that the Bio-
Mother is in therapy, but the agency worker has not had any
communication with her therapist. The PATP dated January 3,
2023, indicates that the Bio-Mother has not been attending
therapy. It is indicated that she was referred to Network 180 due
to relapse and mental health.
Family Team Meeting: An FTM dated January 23, 2023, was
reviewed, and does not document services for the Bio-Mothers
substance abuse problem.
Trauma Screening Checklist: A trauma screening dated January
5, 2023, indicates that Foster Child A received a score of eight. A
trauma screening dated March 28, 2023, indicates a score of
eleven.
3

Case File Health History: The health history does not document
that Foster Child A has been receiving counseling or that a trauma
assessment has been completed.
Case Service Plan: The service plan, dated February 23, 2021,
was reviewed. The service plan was completed by the DHHS
Monitor and prior to agency case responsibilities. The plan
documents the Bio-Mothers significant substance abuse history.
Allegation 2
The Chief Administrator reported that an internal investigation had
been conducted and it was acknowledged that the agency worker
had “cut and pasted” contacts for the months of October,
November, December 2022, and January 2023. The Chief
Administrator reported that she believed that the worker was
making the monthly contacts to the relative’s home but was not
completing the appropriate narratives for each contact, instead cut
and pasting the same narratives for each month.
The Deputy Director acknowledged that the foster care worker
had cut and pasted contact narratives for October, November,
December, 2022, and January 2023.
DOCUMENT REVIEW: The case file was reviewed. In home
contact narratives for October 19, 2022, and November 28, 2022,
are identical. In home contact narratives for December 28, 2022,
and January 27, 2023, are identical.
Analysis Analysis Allegation 1
The Chief Administrator and Deputy Director acknowledged that
appropriate and needed services for Foster Child A and the Bio-
Mother were lacking or delayed. The Chief Administrator reported
that Foster Child A should have been referred for counseling and
a trauma assessment following the January 5, 2023, trauma
screening and this did not occur.
The case file does not document referrals for substance abuse
services for the Bio-Mother until January 3, 2023, following a
November 8, 2022, positive drug screen.
The case file does not document consistent follow up with the Bio-
Mothers therapist.
4

Analysis Allegation 2
The Chief Administrator and Deputy Director acknowledged that
the agency worker had “cut and pasted” four in home contacts,
therefore specific narratives, and safety assessments relevant to
each contact were not completed.
A review of social work contacts for October and November 2022
indicates the contacts were identical duplicates. Contacts for
December and January were also identical duplicates.
In both instances the Chief Administrator described how the
worker failed in her responsibility to provide services to the
biological mother and failed to document quality visits. She failed
in her responsibility to develop and implement, service plans for
this family as required by this rule.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
COMPLAINT: The complaint contained an additional allegation which did not fall
under the regulation of the department.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
